turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Korean fried chicken.
turn.2: Korean fried chicken Korean fried chicken or KFC, usually called chikin (, from the English "chicken") in Korea, refers to a variety of fried chicken dishes from South Korea, including the basic huraideu-chikin (, from the English "fried chicken") and spicy yangnyeom-chikin (, "seasoned chicken").
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: In South Korea, fried chicken is consumed as a meal, an appetizer, "anju" (food that is served and eaten with drinks), or as an after-meal snack.
turn.5: How does it differ from American fried chicken?
turn.6: Korean fried chicken differs from typical American fried chicken because it is fried twice; the skin is therefore crunchier and less greasy.
turn.8: Furthermore, Korean-style chicken is not characterized by the crags and crusty nubs associated with American fried chicken; it was described by Julia Moskin of "The New York Times" as a "thin, crackly and almost transparent crust".
turn.9: Is there anything else different about it?
turn.10: The chicken is usually seasoned with spices, sugar, and salt, prior to and after being fried.
turn.12: Korean fried chicken restaurants commonly use small- or medium-sized chickens; these younger chickens result in more tender meat.
